question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
What is the largest three-digit integer $n$ that satisfies $$55n\equiv 165\pmod{260}~?$$
inference:
We have $55n \equiv 165 \pmod{260}$.
We can simplify this congruence by dividing both sides by 5:
$11n \equiv 33 \pmod{52}$.
We can rewrite this as $11n - 33 \equiv 0 \pmod{52}$.
We have $11n \equiv 33 \pmod{52}$.
We want to find the multiplicative inverse of 11 modulo 52.
$11 \times 5 = 55$, and $55 \equiv 3 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 6 = 66$, and $66 \equiv 14 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 7 = 77$, and $77 \equiv 25 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 8 = 88$, and $88 \equiv 36 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 9 = 99$, and $99 \equiv 47 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 10 = 110$, and $110 \equiv 58 = 6 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 11 = 121$, and $121 \equiv 121 - 2 \times 52 = 121 - 104 = 17 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 12 = 132$, and $132 \equiv 132 - 2 \times 52 = 132 - 104 = 28 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 13 = 143$, and $143 \equiv 143 - 2 \times 52 = 143 - 104 = 39 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 14 = 154$, and $154 \equiv 154 - 2 \times 52 = 154 - 104 = 50 \equiv -2 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 15 = 165$, and $165 \equiv 165 - 3 \times 52 = 165 - 156 = 9 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 23 = 253$, and $253 \equiv 253 - 4 \times 52 = 253 - 208 = 45 \pmod{52}$.
We want $11 \times ? \equiv 1 \pmod{52}$.
Notice $11 \times 23 = 253 = 4 \times 52 + 45 \equiv -7 \pmod{52}$.
$11n \equiv 33 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 24 \equiv 264 = 5 \times 52 + 4 \equiv 4 \pmod{52}$.
$33 \times 2 = 66 \equiv 14 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 24 \equiv 264 = 5 \times 52 + 4 \equiv 4 \pmod{52}$.

$11 \times 25 = 275 = 5 \times 52 + 15 \equiv 15 \pmod{52}$.
$33 \times 25 = 825 \equiv 52 \times 15 + 45 \equiv 15 \pmod{52}$.


$n = 15 \times 15 = 225$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{225}$
ground_truth:
First, we note that $55$, $165$, and $260$ all have a common factor of $5$: \begin{align*}
55 &= 5\cdot 11\\
165 &= 5\cdot 33\\
260 &= 5\cdot 52
\end{align*}An integer $n$ satisfies $55n\equiv 165\pmod{260}$ if and only if it satisfies $11n\equiv 33\pmod{52}$. (Make sure you see why!)

Now it is clear that $n=3$ is a solution. Moreover, since $11$ and $52$ are relatively prime, the solution is unique $\pmod{52}$. If you don't already know why this is the case, consider that we are looking for $n$ such that $11n-33=11(n-3)$ is divisible by $52$; this is true if and only if $n-3$ is divisible by $52$.

Hence all solutions are of the form $3+52k$, where $k$ is an integer. One such solution which is easy to compute is $3+52(20) = 1043$. The next-largest solution is $1043-52 = 991$, so the largest three-digit solution is $\boxed{991}$.

inference:
$55n \equiv 165 \pmod{260}$
Dividing by 5 gives $11n \equiv 33 \pmod{52}$.
We need to find the inverse of 11 modulo 52.
$11 \times 15 = 165 \equiv 165 - 3 \times 52 = 165 - 156 = 9 \pmod{52}$.
$11 \times 19 = 209 \equiv 209 - 4 \times 52 = 209 - 208 = 1 \pmod{52}$.
So the inverse of 11 modulo 52 is 19.
Multiplying both sides of the congruence by 19, we get
$11n \times 19 \equiv 33 \times 19 \pmod{52}$
$19 \times 11 = 209 \equiv 1 \pmod{52}$
$n \equiv 33 \times 19 = 627 \equiv 627 - 12 \times 52 = 627 - 624 = 3 \pmod{52}$
So $n \equiv 3 \pmod{52}$.
$n = 52k + 3$ for some integer $k$.
We need to find the smallest positive integer solution.
If $k=0$, $n=3$.
Then $55n = 55 \times 3 = 165$, and $165 \equiv 165 \pmod{260}$, which is true.
Therefore, $n=3$ is a solution.
$n = 3$
$55n = 55(3) = 165$, which is a solution.
$165 \equiv 165 \pmod{260}$

The general solution is $n = 52k+3$ for any integer $k$.
The smallest positive integer solution is $n=3$.
$\boxed{3}$
ground_truth:
First, we note that $55$, $165$, and $260$ all have a common factor of $5$: \begin{align*}
55 &= 5\cdot 11\\
165 &= 5\cdot 33\\
260 &= 5\cdot 52
\end{align*}An integer $n$ satisfies $55n\equiv 165\pmod{260}$ if and only if it satisfies $11n\equiv 33\pmod{52}$. (Make sure you see why!)

Now it is clear that $n=3$ is a solution. Moreover, since $11$ and $52$ are relatively prime, the solution is unique $\pmod{52}$. If you don't already know why this is the case, consider that we are looking for $n$ such that $11n-33=11(n-3)$ is divisible by $52$; this is true if and only if $n-3$ is divisible by $52$.

Hence all solutions are of the form $3+52k$, where $k$ is an integer. One such solution which is easy to compute is $3+52(20) = 1043$. The next-largest solution is $1043-52 = 991$, so the largest three-digit solution is $\boxed{991}$.
